results.title: We interrupt this program
results.creator_credit: David Frankel, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
On April 13, 1970, Apollo 13, the 23rd manned flight into space, developed problems that threatened the lives of the astronauts on board. The complacency which had accompanied the launch and the disinterest of the general public throughout the mission until problems occurred were quickly dispelled, as every move was monitored by journalists who fed the story to a hungry audience fast becoming hooked on sensationalism. A divide was growing wider between the traditions of the intellectual press and the fast-feed emotional content of the new tabloid journalism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Frankel, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base

results.title: Mare tranquilitatis
results.creator_credit: Frank Marshall, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
It would be the culmination of John F. Kennedy’s dream. On July 20th 1969, after years of development and training, Apollo 11 - with its team of Neil Armstrong, Edward “Buzz” Aldrin Jr., and Michael Collins - is about to land a man on the moon. The world is watching, and America holds its breath as Neil Armstrong takes “one small step for man - one giant leap for mankind.”

results.title: Spider
results.creator_credit: Graham Yost, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
Before America could land on the moon, it had to devise the lunar module named “LEM” or “Spider”. From an idea on a sketch pad to design and construction; through nine years of rigorous tests, successes and failures. 1969 will witness the first ever docking of two manned vessels in space on Apollo 9, and the first flight of a lunar module in the moon’s orbit on Apollo 10. With all systems go, that same year would see the lift-off of Apollo 11.

results.creator_credit: Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
In a year marked by anti-Vietnam war prtesets, when Russia seemed ready to send a man to the moon, Frank Borman, Jim Lovell and William Anders prepare for the launch of Apollo 8, the first ever manned voyage to the moon. Their aim is to reach the moon and remain in lunar orbit, the greatest risk is that they have a single engine that must break their orbit if it is to bring them home safely.

results.creator_credit: Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
19 months and six unmanned flights after the Apollo 1 tragedy, Wally Schirra, Don Eisele and Walt Cunningham are set to become the first trio of American astronauts in space on Apollo 7 - their preparations followed every step of the way by a keen, young documentary crew. Noone can afford to make a mistake that might endanger the life of the mission or the lives of the men.

results.title: Apollo 1
results.creator_credit: David Frankel, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
January 27, 1967. In preparation for the flight of Apollo 1, astronauts Gus Grissom, Ed White and Roger Chaffe undergo a routine test in their space capsule. The test turns into a disaster when a small electrical fire becomes a raging inferno - the lives of three men lost before they even leave the ground. The nation mourns, but the ever-watchful Senate Committee - anxious over the extreme haste and massive expenditure involved in the project thus far - may pull the plug on the entire Apollo project.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Frankel, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base

results.title: Can we do this?
results.creator_credit: Tom Hanks, Michael Bostick, Ron Howard, Brian Grazer, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Clavius Base
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
On April 12, 1961, Russia launched the first man into space leaving a stunned American Space Program in limbo. A call to arms by President John F. Kennedy revitalises the sleeping giant and the nation is united by one aim: to be the first to land a man on the moon before the decade’s end. The Mercury program is launched on May 5th, 1961 when Freedom 7 takes Alan B. Shepard, Jr for a 15 minute, 22 second flight into outer space. However, there’s a lot to be learned in a short time before man can actually go the distance. Astronauts like Jim Lovell, Buzz Aldrin, Ed White, Neil Armstrong and more will have to risk their lives before the first Apollo can reach for the skies.

results.title: Speaking with confidence
results.brief_description: This 6 part series for teachers and students on public speaking covers the areas of understanding different speech types, audience contact, getting started, the ingredients of a speech and delivery. Presented by Brian Tickle.

group_works.title: Starting out: an introduction to public speaking

results.title: Understanding different speech types. Part 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking with confidence”.
This tape covers the different speech types of the procedure, the discussion, the exposition and the response. A sheet providing suggested exercises as well as a speaking checklist (covering areas such as was the talk clear, purpose defined, speech rate and clarity etc) accompanies the video. Presented by Brian Tickle.

results.title: Getting started
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking with confidence”.
‘Getting started’ covers the important speech preparation and presentation areas of researching, speech structure, rehearsal, delivery, dress, presentation and the conclusion. A sheet providing suggested exercises as well as a speaking checklist (covering areas such as was the talk clear, purpose defined, speech rate and clarity etc) accompanies the video. Presented by Brian Tickle.
